Policing, power and politics: a toxic combination?

03/04/2022

Josh Rutland analyses the increasing politicisation of the police as Britain's most senior officer resigns

Image by Simon Dawson / No 10 Downing Street

By Josh Rutland

The resignation of Britainâ€™s most senior police officer last month revealed the inherently politicised nature of modern policing. Dame Cressida Dick, Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, confirmed she would leave her position after the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, announced he had no confidence in her leadership. The announcement came after some of the most challenging years in the Metâ€™s history, plagued by a series of failures and controversies which has tarnished the profession altogether.

The Commissionerâ€™s resignation was confirmed amid another scandal for Britainâ€™s biggest force involving allegations of racism, sexism, homophobia and bullying among officers serving at Charing Cross station with the Womenâ€™s Equality Party launching a mock police appeal to highlight alleged misogyny. This came just weeks after two PCs were jailed for taking photos
of two murdered sisters before sharing the images on WhatsApp.

Cressida Dick is no stranger to scandals, including accusations of blocking an independent report into the 1987 murder of Daniel Morgan, which branded the Met â€˜institutionally corruptâ€™. She was also the Gold Commander during the wrongful fatal shooting of Jean Charles de Menezes in 2005, while presiding over a Â£2.5m investigation into alleged child sexual abuse which ended without a single arrest.

Just last year, the murder of Sarah Everard by Wayne Couzens, a serving Metropolitan Police officer, decimated trust in policing particularly as her murderer had a reputation for making women uncomfortable. Most recently the Met has launched an investigation into alleged parties at 10 Downing Street during the Covid-19 lockdown, termed Operational Hillman, after initially refusing to investigate the claims.

Despite this, the Commissioner had been granted a two-year extension last September with the Mayor of London pushing for three-years. Indeed, Cressida Dick was well-liked in the force while being commended for the Metâ€™s response to a series of terror attacks, an epidemic of moped-enabled crime and increasing diversity in the ranks of the force. She is also the first female and first openly gay Met Commissioner, marking a supposedly progressive era for the Met.

However her departure has left a toxic relationship between the Met, the Mayor of London and the government. She announced her intention to leave ahead of a meeting with Sadiq Khan, with Home Office sources claiming Mr Khan was â€œrude and unprofessionalâ€ for not informing Home Secretary Priti Patel. Deputy Commissioner Steve House later accused Sadiq Khan of failing to follow proper processes in the â€œsackingâ€ of the Commissioner.

The Prime Minister and No. 10 have deliberately stayed out of the debate due to the ongoing Operation Hillman, but the harsh actions of the Mayor suggest party politics is beginning to infect key public services. Khan was accused of similar treatment following the resignation of Dany Cotton, the London Fire Brigadeâ€™s (LFB) former Commissioner, who left after the Grenfell Tower inquiry. She was likewise the LFBâ€™s first female Commissioner, yet departed in 2019 after pressure from City Hall.

New legislation is also enabling politics to seep into policing, notably the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill. This would grant police forces significant new powers to stop disruptive protests which have infuriated campaign groups and even sparked riots in Bristol. Such legislation puts senior officers in a difficult position, balancing the democratic rights of protestors with demands from the government.

In a similar vein, more overt political statements have been condemned too. Despite pockets of serious disorder during the Black Lives Matter protests in June 2020, some officers took the knee showing support for an organisation which has indicated desires to defund the police. The Chief Constable of Kent Police, Alan Pughsley, also took the knee showing this was not an isolated incident.

But the critical question is whether policing and politics can ever be entirely separated. Dame Cressida Dickâ€™s departure brings the total of those resigning to three out the last four Commissioners (with Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe opting for early retirement rather than a resignation). When the Met is tasked with enforcing controversial legislation devised by the same government they are tasked with investigating, senior officers will inevitably be dragged into the political sphere.

Meanwhile the label â€˜institutionally corruptâ€™ will likely follow the Met around for many years to come, with the force prioritising its own image in the same way politicians or the government bury bad news. This is amid a seemingly unending slew of misconduct cases amongst officers, exposing a deeper cultural issue which the next Commissioner must address. The departure of Cressida Dick also highlights a broader power play between the Mayor of London and the Home Office in an increasingly politicised service. Whether the next Commissioner can buck the trend remains unknown, but the police risk irretrievably losing public confidence if the current situation persists.
